questions.q: System specifications are considered "consistent" if:
questions.explanation: Consistency implies no conflicts; it is possible for all requirements to be satisfied simultaneously.
options: There is an assignment of truth values that makes them all true

questions.q: System specifications are "consistent" if:
questions.explanation: If no assignment makes them all true, the system is inconsistent.
options: There is an assignment of truth values that makes them all true

questions.q: System specifications are consistent if:
questions.explanation: Simultaneous satisfaction of all propositions is the definition of consistency.
options: There is an assignment of truth values that makes them all true at the same time
They depend on only one variable

questions.q: A compound proposition that is always true is called a:
questions.explanation: A tautology is true regardless of the truth values of its constituent variables.

questions.q: A compound proposition that is always true is a:
questions.explanation: Example: p OR NOT p is always true.

questions.q: A compound proposition that is always false is called a:
questions.explanation: A contradiction is false for every possible combination of truth values.

questions.q: A compound proposition that is always false is a:
questions.explanation: Example: p AND NOT p is always false.

questions.q: The statement [(p ∨ q) ∧ ¬p] → q is an example of:
questions.explanation: This is Disjunctive Syllogism form. If (p or q) is true and p is false, q MUST be true. It's always valid.

questions.q: A compound proposition is "satisfiable" if:
questions.explanation: Satisfiable means it is NOT a contradiction; there is at least one 'solution'.
options: There is at least one assignment of truth values that makes it true

questions.q: A compound proposition is "satisfiable" if:
questions.explanation: Being satisfiable means it has the potential to be true.
options: At least one assignment of truth values makes it true

questions.q: If a proposition is false for every assignment of truth values, it is:
questions.explanation: Unsatisfiable is synonymous with being a contradiction.

questions.q: Showing a proposition is "unsatisfiable" requires showing it is false for:
questions.explanation: You must prove there is no scenario where it can be true.
options: The first row of the truth table

questions.q: According to De Morgan's Laws, ¬(p ∧ q) is equivalent to:
questions.explanation: The negation of AND is the OR of the negations.

questions.q: According to De Morgan's Laws, ¬(p ∧ q) ≡:
questions.explanation: Often summarized as 'break the line, change the sign'.

questions.q: Showing that ¬(p ∨ q) and ¬p ∧ ¬q are equivalent uses:
questions.explanation: This is the second of De Morgan's laws: negation of OR is the AND of negations.

questions.q: De Morgan's Law states that ¬(p ∨ q) is equivalent to:
questions.explanation: Distributing the NOT over an OR flips it to an AND.

questions.q: The Double Negation Law states that ¬(¬p) ≡:
questions.explanation: Two negatives make a positive in logic.

questions.q: Double Negation Law states that ¬(¬p) ≡:
questions.explanation: It returns to the original value.

questions.q: The Identity Law p ∧ T ≡:
questions.explanation: ANDing with True leaves the original value unchanged (True if p is true, False if p is false).

questions.q: The Identity Law p ∧ T ≡:
questions.explanation: Similar to multiplying by 1 in algebra.

questions.q: The Domination Law p ∨ T ≡:
questions.explanation: If one part of an OR is True, the whole statement is True regardless of p.

questions.q: The Domination Law p ∨ T ≡:
questions.explanation: True dominates disjunction.

questions.q: The Absorption Law p ∨ (p ∧ q) ≡:
questions.explanation: The term (p AND q) is a subset of p; if p is true, the result is true. If p is false, both are false.

questions.q: Two compound propositions are logically equivalent if:
questions.explanation: p ≡ q is the same as saying p ↔ q is always true.
options: Their biconditional statement is a tautology
They have at least one same truth value
One is the negation of the other

questions.q: The logical equivalence p → q ≡ ¬p ∨ q is:
questions.explanation: This is the definition of implication in terms of OR and NOT.
options: Only true if q is true

questions.q: The logical equivalence p → q ≡ ¬p ∨ q is:
questions.explanation: This equivalence allows us to rewrite implications without the arrow operator.
options: Only true if p is true

questions.q: Translating "Every student in this class has studied calculus" (where S(x) means x is in class and P(x) means x studied calculus) results in:
questions.explanation: For 'Every' (universal), we use implication. We only care about x IF x is a student.

questions.q: Translating "Every student in this class has studied Java" (if U is all people) results in:
questions.explanation: Using AND would imply that EVERY person in the universe is a student and studies Java, which is wrong.

questions.q: Translating "Every comedian is funny" (C(x) is comedian, F(x) is funny) results in:
questions.explanation: Pattern: 'All A are B' translates to ∀x(A(x) → B(x)).

questions.q: The sum of two rational numbers being rational is proven using:
questions.explanation: We assume m and n are rational (p), add them, and show the sum is rational (q).

questions.q: In P(x), P is the ____ and x is the ____:
questions.explanation: P stands for Predicate (the property) and x is the subject variable.

questions.q: In the expression P(x), P is the:
questions.explanation: The predicate is the property being ascribed to x.

questions.q: A predicate logic expression P(x) becomes a proposition when:
questions.explanation: Once x has a specific value (is bound), the statement can be evaluated as True or False.
options: A value is assigned to x

questions.q: The symbol ∀ denotes the:
questions.explanation: It represents 'For All'.

questions.q: The Universal Quantifier (∀) means:
questions.explanation: Also read as 'for every' or 'for each'.

questions.q: The symbol ∃ denotes the:
questions.explanation: It represents 'There Exists'.

questions.q: The Existential Quantifier (∃) means:
questions.explanation: Also read as 'for some'.

questions.q: The Existential Quantifier (∃) means:
questions.explanation: It requires finding just one example to be True.

questions.q: The Uniqueness Quantifier ∃!xP(x) means:
questions.explanation: The exclamation mark indicates uniqueness.
options: There is at least one x such that P(x)
There exists exactly one x such that P(x)

questions.q: The uniqueness quantifier (∃!) states:
questions.explanation: It asserts existence AND uniqueness simultaneously.

questions.q: The notation ∃!xP(x) means:
questions.explanation: Only one specific element in the domain satisfies the predicate.
options: There are many x such that P(x)
There exists a unique x such that P(x)
For all x, P(x) is true

questions.q: ∀xP(x) is false if and only if:
questions.explanation: A single counterexample disproves a universal claim.
options: P(x) is true for all x
There is a counterexample (at least one x where P(x) is false)
P(x) is false for all x

questions.q: ∀xP(x) is false if and only if:
questions.explanation: If one element fails P, then P does not hold for ALL.
options: P(x) is true for all x
There is a counterexample (an x for which P(x) is false)
P(x) is false for all x

questions.q: ∃xP(x) is true if and only if:
questions.explanation: Finding one success makes the existential statement true.
options: There is at least one x in the domain for which P(x) is true
P(x) is true for every x
P(x) is false for every x
The domain consists of integers only

questions.q: The negation ¬∀xP(x) is equivalent to:
questions.explanation: To deny 'all are P', you say 'at least one is NOT P'.

questions.q: The negation ¬∀xP(x) is logically equivalent to:
questions.explanation: De Morgan's law for quantifiers: Negation passes through and flips the quantifier.

questions.q: The negation ¬∃xP(x) is equivalent to:
questions.explanation: To deny 'there exists one', you must say 'for all, it is not true'.

questions.q: The negation ¬∃xP(x) is logically equivalent to:
questions.explanation: Existential quantifier flips to Universal when negated.

questions.q: The statement "Every comedian is funny" is expressed as:
questions.explanation: Universal + Implication is the standard form for 'All X are Y'.

questions.q: The statement "Every comedian is funny" is expressed as:
questions.explanation: This construction filters the domain for comedians before checking if they are funny.

questions.q: "There is a student in this class who has not read the book" is expressed as:
questions.explanation: Existential statements ('There is') usually use conjunction (AND) to identify the item and its property.

questions.q: The truth value of ∀x(x+1>x) over all real numbers is:
questions.explanation: Adding 1 always increases the value, so this is always true.

questions.q: If the domain is positive integers, ∃x(x<2) is:
questions.explanation: The positive integer 1 is less than 2, so an example exists.

questions.q: In nested quantifiers, the order of ∀x∀y:
questions.explanation: If both are universal, they can be swapped without changing meaning.

questions.q: In nested quantifiers, the order of ∀x∀y:
questions.explanation: Commutativity holds for identical adjacent quantifiers.

questions.q: The statement ∀x∀yP(x,y) is logically equivalent to:
questions.explanation: Same rule as above.

questions.q: The statement ∀x∃y(x+y=0) over real numbers means:
questions.explanation: For any number x, there is a specific number y (its negative) that zeroes it out.
options: There is one y for all x
Every real number has an additive inverse

questions.q: The statement ∀x∃y(x+y=0) in the domain of real numbers means:
questions.explanation: The y depends on the x chosen (y = -x).
options: There is one number y that works for all x
Every real number has an additive inverse
The sum of any two numbers is always zero

questions.q: The statement ∀x∃y(x+y=0) means:
questions.explanation: This describes the Inverse Property of Addition.
options: There is one y that works for all x
Every real number has an additive inverse
x and y are always zero

questions.q: The statement ∃x∀y(x·y=0) over real numbers is:
questions.explanation: If x is 0, then 0 multiplied by ANY y is 0. So there exists such an x.

questions.q: Which of the following logical equivalences involving quantifiers is FALSE?
questions.explanation: Swapping mixed quantifiers changes the meaning (e.g., 'Everyone loves someone' vs 'Someone is loved by everyone').

questions.q: To translate "Every student in school has a computer or has a friend who has a computer", we use:
questions.explanation: For all x: (x has computer) OR (there exists y such that y has computer AND y is friend of x).

questions.q: The sentence "There is a student whose friends are not friends with each other" translates to:
questions.explanation: If y and z are both friends of x (and distinct), then y and z are NOT friends.

questions.q: When negating the statement ∀x∃y(xy=1), the result is:
questions.explanation: Negation flips ∀ to ∃, ∃ to ∀, and negates the equals to not-equals.

questions.q: The order of quantifiers matters when:
questions.explanation: Mixed quantifiers depend on the scope and order of selection.
options: There is a mix of universal and existential quantifiers

questions.q: Precedence in logical operations places quantifiers (∀, ∃):
questions.explanation: Quantifiers bind to the immediate predicate or parenthesized expression before other operators apply.
options: Higher than all other logical operators
At the end of the order
